ai-mn66:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
ai-mn66:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
ai-mn66:2.2_0: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn66:2.3_0: plunged deep into that forest grove and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn66:3.1_0: Venerable Udāyī also robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
ai-mn66:3.2_0: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn66:3.3_0: plunged deep into that forest grove and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn66:3.4_0: Then as Venerable Udāyī was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
ai-mn66:4.1_0: “The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:4.2_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!”
ai-mn66:5.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, Udāyī came out of retreat and went to the Buddha.
ai-mn66:6.1_0: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-mn66:6.2_0: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:6.3_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’
ai-mn66:6.4_0: For we used to eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
ai-mn66:6.5_0: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
ai-mn66:6.6_0: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of day.’
ai-mn66:6.7_0: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
ai-mn66:6.8_0: ‘But these faithful householders give us a variety of delicious foods at the wrong time of day. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’
ai-mn66:6.9_0: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of day.
ai-mn66:6.10_0: Then we ate in the evening and the morning.
ai-mn66:6.11_0: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
ai-mn66:6.12_0: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of night.’
ai-mn66:6.13_0: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
ai-mn66:6.14_0: ‘But these two things that the Buddha was also given up and let go of our husbands, the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One.’
ai-mn66:6.15_0: Once it so happened that a certain person got some soup during the day. He said,
ai-mn66:6.16_0: ‘Come, let’s set this aside; we’ll enjoy it together this evening.’
ai-mn66:6.17_0: Nearly all meals are prepared at night, only a few in the day.
ai-mn66:6.18_0: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of night.
ai-mn66:6.19_0: In the past, mendicants went wandering for alms in the dark of the night. They walked into a swamp, or fell into a sewer, or collided with a thorn bush, or collided with a sleeping cow, or encountered youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, or were invited by a female to commit a lewd act.
ai-mn66:6.20_0: Once it so happened that I wandered for alms in the dark of the night.
ai-mn66:6.21_0: A woman washing a pot saw me by a flash of lightning.
ai-mn66:6.24_0: When she said this, I said to her,
ai-mn66:6.26_0: I’m a mendicant waiting for alms.’
ai-mn66:6.27_0: ‘Then it’s a mendicant whose ma died and pa died!
ai-mn66:6.28_0: You’d be better off having your belly sliced open with a meat cleaver than to wander for alms in the dark of night for the sake of your belly.’
ai-mn66:6.30_0: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
ai-mn66:6.31_0: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’”
ai-mn66:7.1_0: “In the same way, when some foolish people are told by me they say,
ai-mn66:7.2_0: ‘What’s the point of this trivial, insignificant ascetic?’
ai-mn66:7.3_0: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;
ai-mn66:7.4_0: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.
ai-mn66:8.1_0: Suppose a quail was tied with a vine, and was waiting there to be injured, caged, or killed.
ai-mn66:8.2_0: Would it be right to say that,
ai-mn66:8.3_0: For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.’
ai-mn66:8.6_0: For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”

ai-mn66:9.1_0: But when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,
ai-mn66:9.2_0: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’
ai-mn66:9.3_0: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;
ai-mn66:9.4_0: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.
ai-mn66:9.5_0: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.
ai-mn66:10.1_0: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. And it was bound with a strong harness. But just by twisting its body a little, it would break apart its bonds and go wherever it wants.
ai-mn66:10.2_0: Would it be right to say that,
ai-mn66:10.3_0: for that bull elephant, that strong harness is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke?”
ai-mn66:10.6_0: For that bull elephant, that strong harness is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”

ai-mn66:13.1_0: Udāyī, these four people are found in the world.
ai-mn66:13.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by four?
ai-mn66:14.1_0: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:14.2_0: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
ai-mn66:14.3_0: They tolerate them and don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
ai-mn66:14.6_0: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
ai-mn66:15.1_0: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:15.2_0: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
ai-mn66:15.3_0: They don’t tolerate them but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
ai-mn66:15.4_0: I also call this person ‘detached’, not ‘fettered’.
ai-mn66:15.6_0: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
ai-mn66:16.1_0: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:16.2_0: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
ai-mn66:16.3_0: Their mindfulness is slow to come up,
ai-mn66:16.4_0: but they quickly give them up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
ai-mn66:16.5_0: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it.
ai-mn66:16.6_0: The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.
ai-mn66:16.7_0: In the same way, take a person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
ai-mn66:16.8_0: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
ai-mn66:16.9_0: Their mindfulness is slow to come up,
ai-mn66:16.10_0: but they quickly give them up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
ai-mn66:16.11_0: I also call this person ‘detached’, not ‘fettered’.
ai-mn66:16.13_0: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
ai-mn66:17.1_0: Take another person who, understanding that attachment is the root of suffering,
ai-mn66:17.2_0: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments.
ai-mn66:17.5_0: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
ai-mn66:17.6_0: These are the four people found in the world.
ai-mn66:18.1_0: Udāyī, these are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn66:18.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn66:18.7_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn66:18.8_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn66:19.1_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, ordinary, ignoble pleasure. Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, not to be cultivated.
ai-mn66:19.1_1: then say: ‘This is happiness, I say.’
ai-mn66:20.1_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ...
ai-mn66:20.3_0: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
ai-mn66:21.1_0: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening. Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed.
ai-mn66:21.1_1: Such pleasure should not be afraid of these things, I say.
ai-mn66:22.1_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ...
ai-mn66:22.2_0: This belongs to the perturbable, I say.
ai-mn66:22.4_0: Whatever placing of the mind and keeping it connected has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
ai-mn66:23.1_0: Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption.
ai-mn66:23.4_0: Whatever rapture and bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
ai-mn66:24.1_0: Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption.
ai-mn66:24.4_0: Whatever equanimous bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
ai-mn66:25.1_0: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
ai-mn66:26.1_0: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ...
ai-mn66:26.2_0: But this is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:27.1_0: It’s when, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption ...
ai-mn66:27.1_1: they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has gone beyond it.
ai-mn66:27.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:28.1_0: Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:28.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:29.1_0: It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness.

ai-mn66:29.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:30.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:30.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:31.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:31.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:32.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:32.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:33.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:33.2_0: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
ai-mn66:34.1_0: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. That goes beyond it.
ai-mn66:34.2_0: So, Udāyī, I even recommend giving up the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
ai-mn66:34.3_0: Do you see any fetter, large or small, that I don’t recommend giving up?”
ai-mn66:34.5_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn66:34.6_0: Satisfied, Venerable Udāyī was happy with what the Buddha said.
